topic.title: Plenty of errors around
topic.body: There seem  to be high amount of errors recently, which may or may not be related to my tor connection. Getting error on zeroboard, error on zeroid, and most of them "unknown" errors, with no visible explanation. Anyone experiencing similar?

topic.title: Internet censorship in the World
topic.body:
Recently learned that the Wikipedia has been banned in Turkey since early 2017, among other important webpages of unfiltered news.

We all know about China.

What about other countries? Which country populations should be interested in ZeroNet?

Is there a country where ZeroNet is already blocked?

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
>> What happens if two people use the same keys to modify a site?
> Every content.json file is timestamped, the clients always accepts the newest one.

Yeah, and is there a compulsory time sync? What about fake clocks? Clock in the far future?

> [nofish](#comment_912_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Clients only accept content.json timestamped local time + 1 day in the future. So in worst case you will be locked out for 1 day.

Sounds good, so I only have to write a script to timestamp T+23h any site I want to do a DoS?

Or generally speakingâ€¦ I've seen the external security audit of [gocryptfs](https://defuse.ca/audits/gocryptfs.htm) which touched the general problem of _"We believe the reason these vulnerabilities exist is because gocryptfs doesn't have a clearly spelled-out threat model."_  Have anyone looked around the threat model of ZN and have examined the possibilities related?

Replying to myself: this reminds me to mention [vector clock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_clock) algorithm as the ordering in a completely distributed system.

(And what I was looking for was Google's TrueTime, but that's a completely different topic, really interesting nonetheless.)

> [nofish](#comment_913_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): If you have the private key for the site's address  then yes, you can block updates. (but in that case the site is already fucked up, since you can delete it)The user files are time stamped separately, so you can't cause any problem by that.

(I shall read through the whole architecture one day.) So on any user-input-processing site, like this one, I cannot send out updates which would block others from updating? Only myself? Not the database content or any dynamic files containing our user inputs?

Got a popleft: "This site requests permission: Merger:CDN [Grant]" but there is no explanation. This is a very bad practice, asking for a permission from the user without any explanation since it trains the user to blindly accept anything which is asked. That's the road to hell.
No, I haven't googled, since John Doe won't, either.
zeronet + ipfs? unite instead of diverge? was this point already raised? answered maybe?

Also, does [nofish](#1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj) notifies? It only contains **(#1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj)** without the comment reference.

> [nofish](#comment_1125_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): The notification is looks for your username not your hash: ...WHERE comment.body LIKE '%[nofish%' OR comment.body LIKE '%@nofish%'

So when I reference my friend @nofishythings: then you also get the notification? ;-)

> Easiest way is to click reply on the user's comment and the first line will contain the user's hash

Unless s/he's the original poster and haven't written a comment yet. But since I do not need the hash, it's a moot point.

â€¦unless I actually make the comment that this seems to be a very unreliable way of notification. :-] But looks like something simple to fix. (like `â€¦WHERE comment.body REGEXP '[[@]nofish[: ]'â€¦` without considering the possible problems :-])
[I confess I was still way too lazy to check the relation {the way of communication} between ZeroTalk and ZeroHello, and to see how ZeroHello gathers notification from ZeroTalk and elsewhere. Or, in fact, to check how ZN zites intercommunicate. Ãœbrlazy, I know.]

Analysing (Layer7) firewalls don't care about the port. Only two kind of protocols are resilient to such adversaries:
* those which contain no protocol identifying properties at all (=look like random noise)
* those which look like a different, accepted protocol (web, dns, unless they are filtered, but then you forget internet altogether)

But you're acting ignorant, possibly because you are. Whatsapp is shit, right? And Telegram is cool, eh? You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about. Why don't you start looking around _before_ you open your mouth?
And zeronet has almost nothing common with all the rest. 

But, to the others: Whatsapp security is pretty good, they only - possibly - steal metadata, but not the chat content, since they're using the same signal protocol as, surprise, Signal, which is the state of the art of chat encryption nowadays. Something similarly secure is Wire, and it's additionally much more anonymous than the former ones. OTOH Telegram normal chat is shit, same "security" as Google Hangout or basically whatever central service using TLS, which is absofuckinglutly nothing. Telegram secure chat is a wee bit better, but not that much better than it would earn to be called "useful". XMPP/OMEMO is quite good, but not widespread. That's about all, other are useless. If you want anon use Wire, if you want more security use Signal, if you don't care much about metadata (who do you contact) but want user friendliness use Whatsapp.

Zeronet is not a chat network, and it's not a peer-to-peer data exchange. At least not in that sense. And zeronet "chat" gets basically into a shared, displayed database. Not quite anon, not quite secure; not as bad as telegram, but I wouldn't use it for everyday secure communications. And to shatter the illusion of some: it can be easily filtered. Don't escape into a dream, reality is there even if you turn your head around.

> [helium](#comment_123_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): Except the people, who run the ZeroNet servers. [...]

First, your long post is pretty fine. Thanks.

Then, unfortunately Zeronet doesn't seem to be a good place to archive. Zites are cached when visited, most of the time at least, and they get destroyed on a reinstalled peer. After a while you can expect all the _old_ peers to vanish while there won't be any new ones, so the zite will simply disappear and nobody will notice.
The other problem may be storage space: while ZN is small the required storage is neglectible but when there'd be millions of zites that's a serious amount of gigabytes, and people would start purging manually or force nonofish to implement autopurging, which'd be the end of the illusion of eternity.

> [helium](#comment_151_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): 
You try to reinvent FreeNet, but ZeroNet works a very different way. Here Zites are the unit and people cache only their own interests. 

Theoretically there could be an ArchiveOrg-like ZN site which tries to cache everything available, but it could be prohibitively large pretty fast and act as one point of failure. ZN isn't prepared to be a shared storage, or a long-term storage. Even FreeNet loses bits and bytes everytime, where all the peers get lost and no new ones come around. It's a good best-effort backup, but even for that the current ZN size is way too small, and the expected TTL is pretty low (maximum a few months would be my guess).

1518461623_1R67TfYzNkCnh89EFfGmXn5LMb4hX.body:
https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/help_zeronet/network_protocol/

As far as I see (too lazy to set it back from tor and dump the traffic) the initial connection uses unencrypted 
handshake which makes possible to identify the protocol and flag the conversation sides as zeronet nodes.

I haven't checked whether crypted packets have any unencrypted content like headers, but I guess there are some and it's a clear identification.

Also port 15441 is heavily used, I'm not sure how randomised ports could function without a bootstrap facility. 

Bootstrapping seem to be a problem as well, since these nodes may be firewalled (but it can be avoided by communicating new bootstrap nodes or data by other means).


Generally designing a DPI-resistant protocol could mean either having no identifiable (unencrypted) information in the packets (which should be indistinguishable from binary garbage) or masquerade it as a different, not filtered protocol (like DNS tunnels do with dns), but it's much harder. Binary garbage communication usually require a completely separate channel to synchronise the nodes. 

Technically if a packet is easy to decrypt by anyone *but* looks like random garbage by the DPI then it may be pretty good against normal efforts, since most DPI isn't able to make external packet processing like decryption; they're good in identification and classification only.

Sidenote: _*communism*_ is something absolutely unrelated to your problem. The word you're looking for is **"authoritarian regime"**.

> [kaffie](#comment_588_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Political correctness isn't censorship. It's being polite. 

This is not really true. It's like not saying _fuck_ when the speaker meant fuck, the audience know that it's been fuck, everyone knows that the bleeping means it was fuck, and still the system **forces** you to act like you didn't know, and when you mean it you cannot say it. It is absolutely completely stupid. And as it goes on it starts labeling saying things forbidden, incorrect, unacceptable. It's *doublespeak*: you are forced to say something else instead of what you intend to say.

And doublespeak is an important step towards fascism, as you correctly mentioned. 

I can be fucking nice even using unPC words. And phrases. And topics.

> [kaffie](#comment_590_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): That is censorship, not political correctness. PC would be not calling gay people faggots. Censorship would be literally bleeping out the word faggot. Forcing political correctness would be censorship.

I believe the problem is mixing these up, or maybe that different people connect different meaning to the same word, and plenty of people mean "censorship" when say "PC". 

But along your examples, what do you think when you are forced to say "homosexual person", since "gay" implies men and it is slang; and what when someone figures it would be incorrect to say "homosexual" since it acquired just the same negative connotations as "faggots" and "gays" and you have to use "sexually different preferenced person", until it gets used in the real world, acquire connotations then you can move on a longer, more complex and more meaningless phrase? 

A lovely example are gypsies and Eastern Europe; the word gypsy have all the context of wandering, poor, sometimes petty criminal people, with specific prejudice applied, so the PC leaders thought let's play on language and call the gypsies "roma" (or, even "minorities", in a context where there is only one minority and that's the gypsies). Small problem though: almost one third of them originates from an absolutely different tribe (or whatever the PC word) and they speak a different language and they would never call themselves roma since those are their, um, kind of opposites (if not enemies). So, PC people make 2/3 gypsies satisfied and 1/3 angry. And even that only for a few years, maybe decades, when the words acquire the __same__ connotation, since these are associated with the __concept__ behind the words and not just to the words themselves. In the end we have a new, PC phrase meaning just the same, except that it could be used as it wasn't. 

It's the same as writing "f---- you you a------!" where I know what it means, you know what it means and possibly everyone else know what it means, and we still all play PC. And it's not "censorship" as in removing content by a __third party__, it's been removed collectively in the name of PC.

_update:_ by the way "forcing"; it is possible to create an environment of __fear__ or __pressure__ where people are afraid not to censor out or replace words. They bleep out their own words. Is that censorship? Where's the thin line?
